instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is 3V3_S0SW_LCD? 3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. This is necessary to get an image on the screen.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no image.

It has 20V on ampmeter, it reaches 1.45A, CPU gets hot, it seams to be powering on, but I have no internal image neither external.

Already tried a known good lcd, without success.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
USB activity?
Why the peoples always check for image only?
CPU core voltage behavior???
Any history available?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
HI,

Sorry. After all, it seams that the LCD is working (tried it on another machine and it is OK), and It has external image, but no backlight on internal display, even with other LCD (something was making a bad contact, and after removing the board, it started to work).

<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V, and 0.545 on diode reading.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 5.1V

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL> = 0.085V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Image should appear before backlight.

Do you get 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high at same time.
If not check <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>, pins 2, 3 & 8.
Also check diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL>/P lines.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 0V <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>  = 0V

<CHIP>U8510</CHIP>:
PIN 2 = 0V
PIN 3 = 0V
PIN 8 = 0V

Diode reading:
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> = 0.005
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL>  = 0.225

Is it CPU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> = 0.005"
Yeah, CPU's eDP output is damaged.
On this board, there is no series capacitors as protection.
